module.p: ged (a/nach) although, (even) though is a concessive/contrastive subordinating conjunction.

Pedagogical examples –
Cha do sguir i den obair, ged a bha i claoidhte.
She didn’t stop work though she was exhausted. td. 206
Chì mi e cho math ’s ged a b’ ann an-dè a bh’ ann.
I can see it/him as well as though it were yesterday. td. 206 cho ... ’s ged a ...
Ged a bha mi sgìth cha do stad mi.
(Al)though I was tired I didn’t stop. td. 329
[...] ged a chaidh a mhuinntir a chur às an dachaighean agus an cur thar a’ chuain
[...] though his people were evicted from their homes and sent overseas td. 329
Ged a chuirteadh a-mach e, thigeadh e a-steach a-rithist.
Though he were [to be] put out, he would come back in again. td. 329
Cha tèid Màiri air lathaichean saora ged a bhios an t-airgead aice.
Mary will not go on holiday even though she will have the money. td. 105

Examples from modern usage –
’S e Tòmas an aon chroitear as aithne dhomh a dh’èirich gu inbhe taidhcùn. [...] Bha seachdnar de theaghlach aige, ceathrar mhac agus triùir nighean, agus bha a h-uile fear is tè anns a’ mhalairt ach Rob. B’ e Rob a b’ òige agus lean e an sgoil. Nuair a ràinig e an t-oilthigh bha càch airson gun ionnsaicheadh e cunntasachd, a bhiodh feumail anns a’ mhalairt, ach ’s ann a bha ùidh-san ann an ealain. Dh’fhàg e an t-oilthigh agus chaidh e do sgoil ealain. Bha cuibhreann aige bho athair a bha tuilleadh ’s gu leòr airson fheumalachd ged a bha e dèidheil air a’ bhotal, agus cha robh e a’ dèanamh spàirn sam bith airson faighinn air adhart san t-saoghal. [...]
Thomas is the only crofter I know who has risen to the status of a tycoon. [...] He had a family of seven, four sons and three daughters, and every man and woman was in the business except Rob. Rob was the youngest and he stayed on at school. When he reached the university the others wanted him to learn accountancy, which would be useful in the business, but his interest was in art. He left the university and went to an art school. He had an allowance from his father which more more than enough for his needs even though he was fond of the bottle, and he was not making any effort to get on in the world. [...] td. 5
Ann an Dùn Èideann anns na naochadan bha barrachd agus barrachd inbhich airson Gàidhlig ionnsachadh agus ged a nochd mòran chlasaichean agus cùrsaichean Gàidhlig airson iarrtasan nan daoine sin a fhreagradh, bha ionnsachadh na Gàidhlig ga bhacadh gu mòr air sgàth dìth shuidheachaidhean far an cluinnear an cànan ga bruidhinn gu nàdarra.
In Edinburgh in the 90s there were more and more people wanting to learn Gaelic and although a lot of Gaelic classes and courses sprang up to respond to the demands of those people, Gaelic learning was largely inhibited because of lack of situations where one could hear the language spoken naturally. td. 85

Pedagogical examples –
Ged nach eil sinn fhathast pòst’, tha mi ’n dòchas gum bi.
Though we are not yet married, I am hopeful that we will be. td. 206 song
gar an is an archaic/dialectal alternative to ged nach.
ge-tà however, even so, notwithstanding, though is a contrastive/concessive discourse adverbial. Alternative spellings are ged tha, ged thà.

Pedagogical examples –
Thug iad gealladh-pòsaidh dha chèile; cha do phòs iad, ge-tà.
They got engaged; they didn’t get married, though. td. 207
Ged tha, tha rud no dhà agam ri innse dhuibh.
Even so, I have a thing or two to say to them. td. 329

Derived from Old Gaelic cía although, in spite of the fact that, even though, cf. Roibeard Ó Maolalaigh (2023). ‘An Old Gaelic conjunction rediscovered: Old Gaelic ceni, Scottish Gaelic gar an and related concessive conjunctions in Gaelic’. North American Journal of Celtic Studies 7(1):1–87 link.
